Ingredients: 

• 5 veal shanks (ossobuco), each about 2 inches thick 
• 1 cup all-purpose flour (for dredging) 
• 4 tablespoons olive oil 
• 2 onions, finely chopped 
• 2 carrots, finely chopped 
• 2 celery stalks, finely chopped 
• 4 cloves garlic, minced 
• 1 cup dry white wine 
• 2 cups beef or veal broth 
• 1 can (14 ounces) crushed tomatoes 
• 2 sprigs fresh rosemary 
• 2-3 sprigs fresh thyme 
• Salt and pepper to taste 
• Gremolata (optional, for garnish): 
• Zest of 1 lemon 
• 2 cloves garlic, minced 
• 2 tablespoons fresh parsley, finely chopped 

Procedure: 

1. Dredge and Brown the Veal Shanks: 
• Season the veal shanks with salt and pepper, then dredge them in flour, shaking off any excess. 
• Heat the olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot over medium-high heat. 
• Brown the veal shanks on all sides until they develop a nice, golden crust. Remove and set them aside. 

2. Sauté the Aromatics: 
• In the same pot, add the chopped onions, carrots, and celery. Sauté for about 5-7 minutes until the vegetables start to soften. 
• Stir in the minced garlic and cook for another minute or two. 

3. Deglaze with Wine: 
• Pour in the dry white wine, scraping the bottom of the pot to release any browned bits (fond). 

4. Braise the Veal Shanks: 
• Return the veal shanks to the pot. 
• Add the beef or veal broth and crushed tomatoes. 
• Nestle the fresh rosemary and thyme sprigs among the shanks. 
• Bring the mixture to a gentle simmer. 

5. Simmer and Cook: 
• Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and let it simmer for about 2-2.5 hours, or until the veal is tender and easily pulls apart with a fork. 

6. Make the Gremolata (Optional): 
• In a small bowl, combine the lemon zest, minced garlic, and chopped parsley to create the gremolata. Set it aside. 

7. Serve: 
• Once the Ossobuco is ready, remove it from the pot and discard the herb sprigs. 
• Serve the veal shanks with the braising liquid and sauce, garnished with the optional gremolata if desired. 


Traditionally, Ossobuco is served with Risotto alla Milanese (saffron risotto) or polenta,but it can also be enjoyed with a simple side of mashed potatoes or crusty bread.
